addressleaf.section:
To the Right woorshipfull M
r
Thomas Bodly Esquyer.
In
e Hage.

6 Ja
n
1592 Thomas Brune to M
r
Bodeleie.

page.lettertext:
fol.7r
Right woorshipfull I have according to yo
r
comyshon made dylligent
enquyery for the Father and sonne whose names yow gave me in writing:
but I can nott Learne that any one of them both is here knowen emongest
the M
r
chant
, nor yet emongeste the M
r
Shippers of this towne, wherof
the moste
te are now from home in
Spaigne,
Portugall,
Browage,
and in
e Straytes: Not w
th
stan
d
by cawse this myn enquyery here
made can not suffycyently satysfye yo
r
wo
r
desyre in this behalfe,
I have intreated my Frindes in this towne trading
Hambrough,
Lukeck,
Dansycke,
Melven, and other the Easte
tes to make
enquyery
of the sayed
ties severally, and what eyther of them doeth in those
tes, from
whence I trust to receave advyce within A moneth, whereof I will
advertyce yo
r
w
o
accordingly: Thus in the seeking to learne somewhat
of the
ties knowen by name to yo
r
w
o
I have made enquyerye yf
any shippes of these
tes have byn soulde lately or w
th
in one yeere
into Spaigne, And therby understand that 4 great Shippes
have byn within A yeere sould and delyveryd in Spaygne Vizt 2
of 2
C
Laste one of 250 laste, and one of 3
C
Laste warlyke buylte
w
ch
is come backe agayne by reason that the M
r
and maroners
therof comytted within
e sayed [Shippe] murther of 2 Italyens who
were also in
e same shippe as passengers into Spaygne, w
ch
murther
being eyther dyscoveryd in Spaygne, or theyre guyltie consyenc
fearing yt would be openyd, and theyre fact punyshed, dyscharged
her lading in Spaygne receyved there frayght and [Sodeynly]
de
ted thence and came back withe the sayd Ship into thes
t
where shee yet remayneth, and dareth nott to go anymore into
those
t
, And in November laste 2 other Shippes also, thone
of 250 laste and thother of 350 laste were laden from hence into
the Straytes to be there sould or ells in Spaygne, for so
e Owners of
t h
e
gave comyshon to the M
rs
therof so to doe: And this kynde
of Trade ys not lately begonne but hath byn of many yeeres [.]
in thes contries, and in
e Easte
tes
where
they buylde manye
shippes (better cheape then they can doe here) for that pourpose
and sell them in Spaygne or the Strayt
with theyre lading,
And of Late have buylt shippes of
e Inglyshe moulde and fashon
by Inglyshe Shippe writes, dangerous for
e States of o
r
contrye.
And thus following the course of myne Enquyerie consernyng
Shippes, the buying, and selling therof as aforesayed, I have
byn very desyrous to understand what nomber of Shippes
of 60 laste burden, and upward
are in thes
tes, and also
howe they be furnyshed with Insglyshe Iron Ordynance wherof
great store ys in to this contrie daylly brought
ov
r
bearing the
waight of 9
C
10 12 1 4 16 18 20 and A great many of 22
C
24 & 26
C
and above contrary to
e Intent of any lysence grawnted
to any pryvate
son for any consyderacyon what soever: I have
learned that to this Towne, Northe
Holland,
and other places,
of thes Contries (Besyd
Sealand)
belong, Above Athowsand
besydes having
Busses, and other
smaller shippes,
and hoyes
Sayle the least of 60 laste and so upward vizt 1/4
te of 60 last
thone halfe or 1/2 of one hondrethe last and
e rest being of 150 laste
and 2
C
last, furnyshed with Irone pites to every Ship 6 pites
onely one with another Amount
to above Six thowasande pites:
I am Advertysed of Some other Matt
r
of no small moment, w
ch
e
are to be delyvered by woorde of mouth, whiche I would gladlye
reveale
first
to my
Lord Thresorer
yf I were not in danger and Indetted
for her
Ma
t
and
e
States
but yf ytt woulde
please
my good Lord Th
r
to afourde me A passeporte to come over into Ingland and to
retourne (without any Trouble for any debte) Subscrybed by his
L. and 5 or 6 more of my LL. of her Ma
t
Cownsill,
I will
out of hand repayre into Ingland with all convenyent speede.
fol.7v
And shew my self an honeste and dutyfull subjecte
by
my contrie [enteave] the
benefytt and my self thank
:/ Yf yt seeme good to yo
r
wo
r
to send this my
l
re
unto my Lord Thresorer, I dout not but to understand his Lordshippes
speedy andswer, and [enteave] by yo
r
wo
r
meanes the passeporte I desyere.
Thus ceassing from troubling yow further co
m
ende me and this cawse unto yo
r
w
o
favourable defence
and furtherance
: Amsterdam the 6 daye of January 1592 stilo Anglie.
Yo
r
worshippes moste humble at co
m
and Thomas Brune
